Award.AwardTitle: ABI Innovation: Advanced mathematical, statistical, and software tools to unlock the potential of animal tracking data
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to develop a statistically rigorous analytical foundation for the nascent field of movement ecology. An understanding of animal movement can inform a wide range of biological topics including population and community ecology, animal physiology, disease spread, gene flow, and wildlife management and conservation. Historically, a lack of movement data limited progress, but advances in tracking technology have facilitated the collection of high-quality movement data for an ever-growing number of species. Now, the key bottleneck is the dearth of good statistical tools for extracting information from these accumulating data sources. This research addresses this gap by combining movement-modeling techniques from physics with statistical methods for non-independent data from geostatistics. These next-generation analytical tools will allow biologists to tackle the four key analysis categories in movement ecology: 1) modeling movement paths, 2) estimating kinematic quantities such as velocity and distance travelled, 3) identifying driving relationships between resources and movement, and 4) quantifying animal space use. Outreach efforts will target the diverse array of biologists collecting and asking questions of animal movement data. Specifically, a series of tutorial papers will demonstrate methods covering the four analysis categories on conservation-focused case studies including African bush elephants in Kenya and the endangered khulan in the Mongolian Gobi desert. Additionally, an in-depth training course aimed at conservation practitioners and wildlife managers will be offered, and project results will be incorporated into the graduate and undergraduate curriculum at University of Maryland.

This work combines recent advances in modeling movement as a continuous space, continuous time stochastic process with kriging techniques from geostatistics. Kriging is a statistically optimal method of probabilistically "filling in the blanks" between a limited number of autocorrelated data points. Kriging revolutionized geostatistics and is now the gold standard for interpolating between autocorrelated spatial point observations. Analogously, adapting kriging to movement data will allow researchers to probabilistically reconstruct movement paths from a limited number of location observations. Knowledge of the continuous path an animal traversed is the critical nexus linking animal movement data to a wide range of ecologically-informative and conservation-relevant analyses. These transformative methods therefore have the potential to remove the key roadblock that is currently holding movement ecology back. To fully capitalize on that potential, this project will develop an integrated suite of freely available software packages for the R environment for statistical computing. These packages will enable users to answer movement related questions for a broad range of species with the powerful krige-based analytical tools the project develops. Project results will be available at http://biology.umd.edu/movement.html.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding where animals go, why they go there, and how much habitat they need to survive is critical for wildlife conservation efforts. All around the world, animal tracking datasets are being collected via technologies including the global position system (GPS) and the Argos system. Ongoing technological advances allow these datasets to be collected with ever-shorter time intervals between location observations. This results in both larger datasets overall, as well as in data where observations collected close together in time tend to be very similar to each other, i.e., they are statistically correlated. Such datasets cannot be accurately analyzed with conventional statistical tools, which assume that observations are statistically independent.

 

Intellectual Merit: This project aimed to develop as suite of sophisticated statistical tools for analyzing autocorrelated animal tracking data. The centerpiece of the grant was an adaptation of an optimal model-based interpolation method for spatial fields, known as “kriging”, to timeseries of animal locations (i.e., animal tracking data). Timeseries kriging allows one to “fill in the blanks” in-between location observations in a statistically valid way. This approach facilitates quantifying where the tracked animal could have been located even at times during the sampling period when it was not directly observed. Overall, this work led to a number of methodological breakthroughs including the above-described interpolation method for animal tracking data (timeseries kriging), the largest ever comparison of statistical methods for estimating animal home ranges (based on a dataset of 369 individuals from 27 different species), more accurate methods for estimating animal movement speed and distance traveled from tracking data, faster computational algorithms for analyzing animal tracking data that facilitate analysis of larger datasets, and improved methods for fitting movement models to tracking data. Collectively, these tools significantly expand the range of analyses that can validly be performed on animal tracking data, and allow researchers to extract more information from such data about animal movement behavior. A key focus of this project was to produce freely available, open source software to implement the statistical methods developed during the project. Great emphasis was placed on making the software as user friendly as possible. The continuous-time movement modeling (ctmm) software package for the R statistical computing environment implements all of the statistical methods developed under this grant. Going a step further, ctmmweb builds an intuitive graphical user interface on top of the computational foundation provided by ctmm. This graphical program is intended to open the statistical tools developed under this grant to a much wider user audience, including wildlife and conservation professionals, as well as students and beginning researchers.

 

Broader Impacts: This project also featured a significant training component, with project participants contributing to 7 AniMove.org training courses and several workshops, which collectively trained over 200 students, postdocs and professionals. This includes two training courses given in 2019 that were based entirely on the ctmm and ctmmweb software packages developed under this grant. In addition, this project provided numerous opportunities for undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdocs to participate in project-related research activities. A key applied outcome of this award is the recent adoption by Idaho’s Department of Fish and Game (IDFG) of the ctmm software package for estimating wildlife corridors from animal tracking data. This functionality is directly based on the timeseries kriging methods developed in this project. IDFG is using to ctmm to implement the guidance recently set forth in the Bureau of Land Management's Special Order 3362 (https://www.blm.gov/policy/ib-2019-005) to identify and better protect migration corridors for big-game species (e.g., Rocky Mountain Elk, Mule Deer, and Pronghorn Antelope) occurring on Federal lands.
